reviews.review_text: A Need for Speed game set on circuits rather than streets.   Need for Speed: Shift is a somewhat okay racing game, aimed mostly at the people who prefer sitting back with a controller just driving some fast cars around fast tracks with all assists turned on. I can imagine it does a pretty good job at that.  But if you jump into it expecting something more, you are in for a big disappointment. I would not even go as far as calling it a mix of an arcade and a simulator, simply because it is a pure arcade which stays true to the Need for Speed name. The game revolves around ramming into each other, the AI is bad and so are the physics, the controls are poor all the way from the menu to the game itself and the unnecessary blurry speed effects and the deep voice-over about how you are a 'totally cool driver now' do not really save this title - only make it feel more cringeworthy.  Now, I am not trying to make it look as bad as possible. The game is all good as an arcade, is nice to look at, there is a lot of cars to pick from and you can even customise them to a certain degree. And obviously, I would be stupid to expect realism from a Need for Speed title. I just do not think it deserves to be promoted as a simulation experience - and it is, as of now, being promoted as a simulation experience.

I've never been a fan of racing games in my earlier life, and NfS: Shift is probably the only game that I instantly liked when I first played it.  The only true way to 'fully play' this game is to put all of the difficulty sliders on the simulation dificulty. Only then, you'll find out how rewarding racing a car can be. Especially since it is really difficult to keep it stable at high speeds and in tight turns.  The graphics in this game are clean and sharp. Textures could be better, though car detail is ample and greatly refined. Interior cockpit view is also done admirably. The sound feels too fake at times. Especially when you have games like DiRT 2 and 3, that use a sound system that is near indistinguishable from the real thing.  A good game, excellent for drinking games and arcade race players. Drive one round, whenever you miss a turn and spin out, you ♥♥♥♥ing chug.

Let me review this game while it's still fresh in my mind. After 29 hours, I finished the game. Granted - I'm missing about 10 stars out of 1125 or something, but the requirements for those stars are so arbitrary, I'm not even going to bother.  Graphics: 4/5 Sound: 5/5 AI: 2/5 Replayability: 2/5 Online: 0/5 Soundtrack: -20/5  This game has its highs and lows. I will say that the interior views for the cars are amazing - NFS: Shift is the only game I've played that featured a cockpit view of the AE86, which not even Polyphony Digital (makers of Gran Turismo) could not do. Aside from the cool interiors, decent HUD effects, and sound, the game is not really all that great.  The AI is absolute trash, and WILL ram you on turn one of any track. The thing that disgusted me the most was the gratuitous use of rubberbanding, which only activated once the AI realizes you have a good chance of passing them.  The in-race missions are okay, except for the ones that require you to spin out/tap out an opponent. As a racing game veteran, there is nothing that I hate more than dirty racing, and this game requires you to smash opponents for stars in certain races. To add insult to injury, when you DO attempt to smash the enemies, you might as well be crashing your car into a wall, because pit maneuvers and other various tactics do not work, and instead will spin you out.  Sometimes, races require you to perform clean laps as a mission. This is extremely do-able on tracks with more than one lap. This is NOT do-able on Nurburgring. Because of Nurb's narrow track, and the AI's awful racing line, you will either be hit, or you will hit someone. If you try to race clean, you will never make it into first. That was another mission I did not bother doing.  Online was non-existent. I selected quick match at peak online gaming hours (10pm EST - 2am EST) and did not find a single match. The game still gave me the option to create a match, and I could post my leaderboard stats online, so I arrived at the conclusion that the servers are up, but nobody plays this online.  I completed this game because I enjoyed NFS as a kid. If I had to rank it out of games that I've played out of the franchise, I'd rank it NFSU2 > Pro Street > Shift > NFSU1.  I picked this game up for $5 because it was on sale, and I think that is the only circumstance that you as the reader should pick this up. This game is NOT worth $20.  The soundtrack is ridiculously ♥♥♥♥ too. I just played the game with my Eurobeat collection running in the background.

This is the only Need For Speed game I've played that I didn't care for, and I've been following the franchise since the days it released on 3DO! 1994, was it? Anyway, this feels as far from NFS as it can possibly get. Sure, it's an ok game, but the NFS standard has been raised so high for it to be dropped on its head like this.  Maybe it was better back in the day, but it pales in comparison with other NFS titles, mainly NFS: Hot Pursuit (whether you're talking about the new one from 2010, or the older one, NFS3:HP from 1998). The handling of the cars is atrocious, and other reviewers have done a far better job of explaining its shortcomings than I ever could, but steering sucks, acceleration sucks (AI can always accelerate faster than you even when you're in the same cars, and they can always corner better than you can by supplanting the physics of the game and taking curves without sliding; you aren't allowed to do that though!). Touch the steering wheel at the wrong time and you spin out. Run off the track for more than a second, and you get a warning and your time doesn't count. Run off the track too many times, and it's race over for you! Come to a complete stop and then wait about 5 seconds for the game to register that you can drive again. Hate a particular trial? Too bad, you have to master it to continue. Forget overtaking your opponent on most of the time trials...unless you get in front of him somehow in the first turn, he's gone and you can never catch up; you have to get right in front of him and stay there, blocking him from passing the whole time. Not fun!!  The unacceptable cons of this game make it unenjoyable to me. Pair that with racetrack only driving and it's not enough to keep me interested.  Sorry to say this is my least favorite NFS game I've ever played, and I have played most of them with the exception of maybe Undercover, Rivals, World, and The Run. It never offers anything fun and exciting, just frustration and more frustration.
